Whispers 'I love you' to Sydney, showing emotional openness and sincerity.
Maintains calm and composure when confronted about missing money, but provides evasive answers.
Manages to maintain composure and honesty when confronted about missing money, confidently naming Victor Tellegio and Alfonse Simone as holders of the money.
Appears physically and emotionally vulnerable after an incident (needing help to his feet, laying down, broken glasses), suggesting a momentary lapse in control or strength.
Maintains calm and tries to deflect blame, insists on innocence despite accusations.
Turns blame back on Richie, suggesting Richie might be responsible and questions his integrity.
Questions Richie Dimaso's accusation and cleverly suggests Richie himself may have the money, undermining the prosecution's case.
Feigns ignorance about the missing money but maintains composure, attempting to stay in control of the situation.
Relies on Sydney's non-verbal cues but neither he nor Sydney seem to have a clear understanding of the situation regarding the missing money.
Persuasively argues that high-profile arrests must be handled carefully to avoid the appearance of gross incompetence, showing awareness of public perception and strategic thinking.
Uses an example involving mistaken identity of a lawyer’s office to illustrate the FBI’s error, demonstrating his ability to identify flaws in others’ competence.
Warns Richie that the story of being conned does not look good for him, tries to make Richie reconsider the narrative to protect them all.
Shows understanding of the situation's irony and offers a critical perspective about who is targeted unfairly.
Reflects on the successful takedown of major corrupt figures, showing awareness of the impact of their actions.
Expresses understanding of the complexity of the case, noting some targets were 'just doing business' while others knowingly engaged in crime.
Feels haunted by the loss of friendship with Carmine Polito after his arrest.
Moves in together with Sydney, suggesting a close personal relationship.
Stares at Rosalyn after she mentions her injury, showing concern or interest.
Gives back two million to reduce Carmine's sentence, showing strategic thinking and negotiation skills.
Feels haunted by the loss of Carmine's friendship despite the deal, indicating personal regret but not lack of competence.
Richard Dimaso's name never mentioned in the story, implying careful management of information.
Moves in with Sydney and reflects on Rosalyn without apparent conflict or missteps.
Defends Pete Musane by insisting he never took a nickle, refusing to let him get in trouble.
Accepts Rosalyn's farewell gesture without argument, nods and moves on calmly.
Walks hand in hand with Sydney and Danny, indicating connection and affection.
Recognizes the importance of protecting his associates by never letting them take a nickle and thereby avoiding legal consequences.
Decides to leave behind conning and reinvents himself with a legitimate business, securing a bank loan for an art gallery.
Disposes of the nail finish from Rosalyn, symbolizing leaving past behaviors behind and focusing on grounded future plans.
